Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Housing Instability, Foreclosures and Family Health

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Mary Pattillo
Carol Heimer
Elyse Kovalsky
Northwestern University

Home foreclosure, once a rare occurrence, became widespread in some parts of the U.S. during the recent economic downturn. Previous research suggests that people have increased health problems during times of housing instability, but the reasons for this negative association are not clear. The primary objective of this dissertation is to better understand the mechanisms that explain the relationship between foreclosure and health. The researchers will study families' experiences of housing instability in Stockton, California, a city hard hit by the foreclosure crisis. The project draws on interviews with and long-term observations of families at different stages of homeownership, including families who have already experienced foreclosure, families at risk of foreclosure, and families not presently at risk of foreclosure. The foreclosure process can bring changes in families' financial situations, in where they live and in their social ties. These changes create the possibilities for a wide range of health-related effects. The salience of potential mechanisms identified will also be tested through quantitative analysis of aggregated data on foreclosure and health from California cities. This study focuses on families whose hold on a middle class lifestyle and identity is tethered closely to the idea of homeownership. The investigation will build new theoretical tools for the study of inequality and disadvantage across domains of social life. By identifying mediating processes linking economic and housing instability to health, the study can serve as a framework for thinking about similar connections to other domains.

Broader Impacts

The results of this research have implications beyond the near-term impacts of a family losing their home, and beyond the recent economic crisis. After foreclosure, families may continue to struggle with ruined credit and disrupted lives. Similarly, the experience of foreclosure has parallels to other life events associated with financial distress and economic precariousness, such as eviction, job loss and divorce. Insights from this study can be tested in these other cases of families? experience of social or economic shocks. The mechanisms identified by this study may guide policy in the areas of housing and health. To this end, a major goal of the study is translating research findings to a broader audience of local, state, and federal policymakers designing interventions for families struggling with foreclosure, eviction or homelessness.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study sheds light on how American households experience economic insecurity and highlights the degree to which these experiences are shared across social and economic strata. It provides an in-depth view of how insecurity reaches into many aspects of family life—from compromising health, to limiting the ability to participate in social life, to threatening a family’s housing stability—by examining the experiences of households struggling with homeownership and foreclosure.

I conducted interviews with members of 32 households, including 3 families that participated in an ethnography over approximately two years. These households reflect a range of experiences with homeownership, from recent first-time homebuyers to households several years post-foreclosure. The study took place in Stockton, California, a Central Valley city among the hardest hit in the U.S. by the foreclosure crisis. Through the interviews and ethnography, I collected data on household finances, decision-making, and many other areas of family life. I also included interviews with 15 local professionals who support families in different ways, providing an additional perspective on families' struggles with homeownership and economic insecurity.

This project was successful in recruiting households with a wide range of experiences and from a wide range of backgrounds. The sample reflects local diversity with regard to race and ethnicity, education level, immigration status, language background and other characteristics, while simultaneously pointing to shared experiences across the population and to the widespread precariousness of central components of the American Dream, including homeownership and economic stability. One strength of the study is that it involved multiple interactions with some families and incorporated families at various points along the trajectory from homeownership to foreclosure. These varied interactions allowed me to gather data on the range of strategies families relied on to navigate challenges, and on the contexts in which it was more or less difficult for families to regain stability after an experience like foreclosure.

Data from the interviews and ethnography suggest that many households experience cascading losses, stemming from efforts to maintain stability and from the foreclosure itself. The effects of some losses became more apparent over time, suggesting that to date we may not have fully captured the effects of the foreclosure crisis on households and communities. Specifically, participants’ experiences indicated continuing effects on physical and mental health, wealth building and deterioration, access to credit, and the educational trajectories of young adults. For example, participants’ own accounts and those of others in their networks suggested several health-related effects in the short- and long-term for household members as they dealt with threats to their security. These included the onset of stress-related conditions including diabetes and high blood pressure, depression, and at the extreme, suicide. In this study, this relationship was especially pronounced in Latino families.

As they attempted to avoid or mitigate a foreclosure, households spent down savings, borrowed additional sums, relied on family and friends in new ways, compromised their health through overwork, shifted educational plans for themselves or their children, and relocated to new communities. Each of these strategies has its own set of effects on families. Scholars interested in documenting the full effects of the foreclosure crisis or other aspects of the Great Recession may use these findings as a framework for thinking about how to capture and assess the full social and economic costs of these events, on the household and community levels.
